bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p:
No. 52 U.S. Consulate, Goree Dakar Oct.27th 1886
To the Honorable James D. Porter Ass't Secretary of State
Sir, Before American merchants can fairly compete with Europeans in the opening markets of the World, they must learn that in some countries superior packing is held to be a factor fof prime importance: that in places where good are not to be had and there are but few practiced laborers, egg-slate packages, no matter how choice the Goods they contain, are sure to be discriminated against. And this American fault in packing is the more ot be regretted because it is precisely in those countries when the best of packing is of necessity required that the profits are always the greatest.

where heads have follow out, so that the condition in which a shipment of American Flour justly reaches the warehouse of the foreign buyers is often such as to excite his disgust if not his indignation. The buyers of flour in intertropical countries are seldom men who like making up for omissions of shippers by comparing barrels themselves under a brailing sun, and the upshot of the matte is, they give their preference to foreign flour because the packages are better, only dealing with Americans just enough to keep their European Agents from imposing high prices on them.

There is also much prejudice against American Flour-barrels because they do not sufficiently exclude the air, which causes the Flur to spoil quickly. French flour- barrels besides being lined with paper have thirty hoops each and the heads well secure. Such

Among the articles which Americans are interested to export abroad, but which frequently are not packed sufficently well for the purpose. Flour may be intended as disering perhaps the first notice. Almost all newly developed countries consume Flour largely, and as payment in such countries is usually made in saw products which Americans require for manufactoring purposes, there s a double motive for dealing with them direct, which dealing Americans shoulf not forego by refusing to take into account the necessities of their situation. Now in such countries, where teams are always scarce, such articles of Flour have sometimes ro be transported quite long distances by rolling, with are American od having a continued white trail of flour all along the route, interperend have and there with heaps of it mixed and dit-

packages present their contents against even wet, and other things being equal it would be indeed disposing if foreign flour thus protected were not preferred in way competition market. American Flour- barrels for export should have at least sixtee well- driven hoops each: the chimes should be well protected and
